author: Jen
title: Ultra-Brexiteers are ‘totally un-British’ says John Major
text:
Sir John supported Remain (Picture: EPA) Sir John Major has attacked ‘ultra Brexiteers’, saying the way they shout down opponents is ‘profoundly undemocratic and totally un-British.’ 
The former PM said so-called ‘ultras’ who want a total break with Europe are putting the country at risk, and claimed they won the referendum last year with ‘fake facts and bogus promise.’
Toddler dies, another critically injured in London He said that he was worried by seeing ‘vitriolic and personal attacks’ on people who disagreed with them – they ‘demean both themselves at their cause.’
Writing in the Mail on Sunday, he warned if Britain failed to strike a deal with the remaining EU member states and was forced to fall back on World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules – as some hardline Brexit supporters suggest – it would be ‘disadvantageous in every way’.
He wrote: ‘It is time for the minority of ‘Ultra Brexiteers’ – those who believe in a complete break from Europe – to stop shouting down anyone with an opposing view. It is not only unattractive but profoundly undemocratic and totally un-British.’
We are living in a world where #john major , Ken Clarke & Michael Heseltine are deemed traitors for speaking against madness #REMAIN 
— jesuiseu ❄️ (@48notwrong) March 19, 2017 
John Major accuses Brexiteers of 'personal abuse'. What about Remainers calling Leavers uneducated racists? There's abuse on both sides.
— Kelly Wood (@kellywood_5) March 19, 2017 

Sir John did not name names, but his comments will be seen – at least in part – as being aimed at leading Leave campaigners such as Boris Johnson, Michael Gove, Iain Duncan Smith and Jacob Rees-Mogg.
Rugby player returns to game after being told he'd never walk again He said: ‘If the rancour merely came from rabble elements, or extreme minorities, it could be ignored.
‘But when it comes from politicians, including those from within the governing party, it is time to confront it.’
Other Brexit supporters should disown ‘vitriolic, personal’ attacks on judges, civil servants, foreign politicians and other public figures, he urged.
Sir John also dismissed claims by some Brexiteers that Britain could thrive under WTO rules, warning that 90% of UK exports to the EU would become more expensive, with tariffs that would add about £6 billion to their costs.
He said those making those claims were the same ones who said we could give an extra £350 million a week to the NHS, that ‘nobody is threatening our place in the single market’ and that there definitely wouldn’t be a second Scottish referendum.
‘We already know that all three of the above – and much else – were fake facts and bogus promises,’ he said.
‘It was dishonest and wrong to promise the British people an easy, favourable deal with the EU, wrong to promise swift new trade deals, and wrong to state that the Irish peace process would not be unsettled by Brexit.’
